message.content:
Different countries and regions use different plug types based on the adopted national electrical standards. Consequently, it is essential to have a power adapter when travelling to ensure that your electronic devices can be connected and are compatible with the local voltage system.

A power adapter is an accessory that allows you to connect your device's plug (such as a phone charger, laptop charger, or any other electrical device) into outlets in foreign countries. These adapters do not convert voltage; they only help establish a connection between your plug type and the host country's sockets.

The United States primarily uses Type A and Type B plugs classified by IEC as NEMA 1-15 (Type A) and NAMERA 5-15 (Type B). Therefore, if an American travels outside North America or visits countries like Europe or Asia with different socket systems such as Types C, D E/F etc., they will need a power adapter for their US-based electronic devices.

Conversely, if someone from Europe or another part of the world comes to visit the United States with their native European-style plug type C/E/F etc., they would need an appropriate travel adapter for US sockets so their appliances work properly.

Here's a brief overview of some common international connector types:

1. Type A: Primarily found in North & Central America
2. Type B: Primarily found in North & Central America
3. Type C: Found throughout Europe (except UK), South America & Africa
4. Type D: Mostly encountered in India; also used in Nepal & Pakistan.
5.strip_type_e(e.g.: "found_across")
